Award.AwardTitle: Idealized Models for Tropical Climate Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates fundamental questions in tropical climate dynamics through the development and use of idealized models. Simple models are of interest because the chains of cause and effect are less intricate than in sophisticated climate and atmospheric circulation models. The project has two components, the firsts of which is an investigation of the interaction of extratropical baroclinic eddies (essentially frontal weather system) with the Hadley circulation (i.e. the large-scale overturning circulations in the tropics) and the intertropical convergence zones (ITCZs, or zones of enhanced cloudiness and rainfall near the equator). The influence of extratropical eddies on the trade winds and the zonally averaged tropical rainfall distribution will be a primary focus of the research. The second component of the research involves development of methodology for applying the weak temperature gradient (WTG) approximation to single column models (SCM) of the atmosphere. The WTG approximation is a simple representation of the fact that tropical atmospheric temperatures are horizontally homogeneous because of the geostrophic adjustment process, and work conducted here will advance understanding of the implications of the approximation for the behavior of SCMs and the observed tropical atmosphere. In particular, the extent to which the SCM can mimic the dependence of precipitation (a key SCM output) on tropical sea surface temperature, surface wind speed, and horizontal moisture advection in a state-of-the-art climate model.

In addition to advancing the science of tropical climate dynamics, the project has broader impacts through the training and education of a graduate student and a postdoctoral research associate. In addition, source code for software developed over the course of the project will be made available online for the use of the research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The weather and climate of the tropics are different from those of higher latitudes. Because the sun shines more strongly near the equator, the tropics are warmer, and the air contains more water vapor. This makes humidity and clouds play more important roles in the dynamics of tropical weather. Also, because the surface of the earth at the equator is oriented perpendicular to the planet’s axis, the earth’s rotation has a different (and weaker) influence on tropical weather compared to extratropical – that is, higher latitude – weather.

Our project aimed to understand the fundamental physics of tropical weather by focusing on these key aspects, and designing idealized models accordingly. What we mean by an idealized model is one which simulates the real atmosphere, but consciously eliminates some of its complexities. The intent is that the simpler system will be easier to understand, while still replicating the most important features of the real atmosphere.

Much of our project focused on a method of idealization called “parameterization of large-scale dynamics”. We use a sophisticated numerical model to simulate clouds  (and the winds and other weather phenomena that go with them) using the laws of physics in a small region. We typically simulate, say, a patch of atmosphere over an ocean surface few hundred km long and a few hundred km wide. In that region, the weather is simulated accurately, but the rest of the earth’s atmosphere is not present in the model at all. This would normally be a serious limitation, because real weather systems are closely connected to the global circulation of the atmosphere. If that connection is missing, the “clouds in a box” would be individually realistic, but collectively unrealistic because they would be existing in artificial isolation, without the larger-scale circulations.

Our parameterizations of large-scale dynamics get around this by representing those larger-scale circulations in a relatively simple way. The clouds in the box get the feedback and interaction they need as though the global atmospheric circulation were really there, but we don’t have to spend the computer power to explicitly simulate that global circulation. We can get away with this shortcut because we understand some basic things about how the global atmospheric circulation works in the tropics. The most important constraint is that the temperature of the atmosphere is nearly constant throughout the tropics, at any given height. That is, the temperature drops quickly with height, but doesn’t change much as one moves horizontally. We understand why this is, according to the physics of the atmospheric circulation, and this allows us to construct our idealized models and obtain realistic results from them.

In our project we used these models to study a range of different phenomena. Many of the studies looked at how clouds, humidity, and rain change in response to various external influences and processes. For example, we studied how vertical wind shear – the change in the horizontal wind with height – affects tropical clouds. We also studied how clouds interact with atmospheric radiation. In these studies we found interesting relationships that can help us understand specific weather phenomena. As one example, we gained some insight into how wind shear and electromagnetic radiation (i.e., sunlight and infrared radiation emitted from the earth) work together with clouds in something called the “Madden-Julian oscillation” (MJO). The MJO is a giant tropical weather system which influences weather around much of the world. Our knowledge of it gives us some ability to predict weather more than two weeks ahead of time, but we still need to understand better how it works.
